qas.question: What is the fine Art Nouveau villa called?
Who built the European Court of Human Rights building?
What is considered to be the finest building?
Who built the Palais des Fetes?
What building style is the Cite Rotterdam?
Who was the architect for the Hotel Brion?
Who created the Cite de la Musique et de la Danse?
Who designed the Hotel du Departement?

context: As for modern and contemporary architecture, Strasbourg possesses some fine <b6_0>Art Nouveau<b6_0/> buildings (such as the huge Palais des Fêtes and houses and villas like <a0_0>Villa Schutzenberger<a0_0/> and Hôtel Brion), good examples of post-World War II functional architecture (the Cité Rotterdam, for which <a1_0><b7_0>Le Corbusier<b7_0/><a1_0/> did not succeed in the architectural contest) and, in the very extended Quartier Européen, some spectacular administrative buildings of sometimes utterly large size, among which the <a4_0>European Court of Human Rights<a4_0/> building by <a2_0><b8_0>Richard Rogers<b8_0/><a2_0/> is arguably the finest. Other noticeable contemporary buildings are the new Music school Cité de la Musique et de la Danse, the Musée d'Art moderne et contemporain and the Hôtel du Département facing it, as well as, in the outskirts, the tramway-station <a3_0>Hoenheim-Nord<a3_0/> designed by <b5_0><b9_0>Zaha Hadid<b9_0/><b5_0/>.
